moves.7. Be2: Release the pin and permit the castle.
moves.7... Ng8: Knight retreats to the only safe place
moves.8. O-O: Castled.   Note the contrast in development.
moves.8... f6 9. f4 Qc5: Aiming for an exchange of queens.
moves.10. c3: I prefer to recapture giving a strong pawn center.
moves.11... fxe5 12. fxe5: I now have a strong pawn center and mostly developed pieces. Black only has a developed bishop.
moves.13. Nc3: Knight heads out on its classic march.
moves.13... d6: This is a start of an attack onto the pawn center.
moves.14. Nd5:
This is effectively the winning move.  Everything goes downhill from here for black.
I am threatening Nxc7+ However the king needs to defend the bishop.
moves.14... Kd8: Black decides to keep the rook. (Why not Rb8?)
moves.15. Rxf8+: Now the rook is where it wants to be1
moves.16. Bg4+: Adding more pressure to the attack
moves.18... Nxe7: Swapping a knight for a rook
moves.19. Rxh8 Rxc8: Now trading a bishop and rook for the other rook
moves.21... Kc6 22. Bd2: This gets my rook into play
moves.22... Ne7: Passed pawns should be treated like a dangerous criminal (A.N.).
moves.23... Kd5 24. g4: Lets see if black will take the poison pawn
moves.25... Kc5 26. Bxg7: I get my pawn back with interest.
moves.26... a6: Another bad move. I had expected Ng8
moves.28. e7:
The passed pawn makes its break.  At which point black resigns.  
If the exchange had gone ahead white would have two passed pawns the wrong side of a rook.
